short_description: This function generates combinations of frequent baskets
long_description: The CFilter function is a general-purpose collaborative filter.

input_tables.name: InputTable
input_tables.rDescription: Specifies the name of the table that contains the data to filter.
input_tables.description: Specifies the name of the table that contains the data to filter.

output_tables.name: OutputTable
output_tables.rDescription: Specifies the name of the output table that the function creates. The table must not exist.
output_tables.description: Specify the name of the output table that the function creates. The table must not exist.

argument_clauses.name: TargetColumns
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the input table columns that contain the data to filter.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the names of the input table columns that contain the data to filter.

argument_clauses.name: JoinColumns
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the input table columns to join.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the names of join columns, which the function uses as follows: The function uses the items in each join column to define groups of items listed in the input columns. The function tries to identify items in each input column that often appear in the same group. For example, a join column might contain a list of sales transactions from a store, and the input column might contain each individual item purchased at the store. A sales transaction can include multiple items. For each sales transaction, the function tries to identify items that often appear in the same sales transaction (that is, items that are often purchased together).

argument_clauses.name: PartitionColumns
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the input columns to copy to the output table. The function partitions the input data and the output table on these columns. By default, the function treats the input data as belonging to one partition. Note: Specifying a column as both an add_column and a join_column causes incorrect counts in partitions.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the names of the input columns to copy to the output table. The function partitions the input data and the output table on these columns. Note: Specifying a column as both an partition_column and a join_column causes incorrect counts in partitions. This argument makes the function output nondeterministic unless each partition_column is unique in the group defined by JoinColumns (for more information, see Nondeterministic Results). Default behavior: The function treats the input data as belonging to one partition.

argument_clauses.name: PartitionKey
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the names of the output column to use as the partition key. The default value is 'col1_item1'.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the name of the output column to use as the partition key. Default: 'col1_item1'

argument_clauses.name: MaxDistinctItems
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the maximum size of the item set. The default value is 100.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the maximum size of the item set. Default: 100 Note: The function uses max_item_set to determine the size of the data structures it uses to accumulate intermediate results. If the number of distinct items in an target_column is greater than max_item_set , the function might report incorrect results without an error message.

argument_clauses.name: SequenceInputBy
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the LIST_VECTOR of column(s) that uniquely identifies each row of the input argument INPUT_ARG_NAME. The argument is used to ensure deterministic results for functions which produce results that vary from run to run.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the input column(s) that uniquely identify each row of input table. The format is 'input1:c1' where input1 refers to the alias used by the input table that contains such column named c1.
